hints.content: Start by understanding the problem statement clearly. You are on an infinite x-axis and can move left or right from a starting position. Remember that you have a maximum number of steps, k, that you can take.
Consider how the positions of fruits are given. The fruits array is sorted by position, which can help you optimize your search for the maximum fruits you can harvest.

Think about the boundaries of your movement. You can only move to positions that are within k steps from your startPos. This means you need to calculate the farthest left and right positions you can reach.
When you move, you harvest fruits at the position you reach. Make sure to account for the fruits you collect at your starting position if it contains fruits.
You might want to visualize your movement. For example, if you start at position 5 and can move 4 steps, the farthest positions you can reach are 1 (5-4) and 9 (5+4).

Consider using a two-pointer technique. One pointer can represent your current position, while the other can help you track the maximum fruits harvested as you explore positions within your step limit.
Remember that fruits disappear after you harvest them. This means you should keep track of which fruits you have already collected to avoid double counting.
Think about edge cases where k is very small or 0. For instance, if k is 0, you can only harvest fruits at your starting position, if any.
You can also consider cases where there are no fruits within your reachable range. Make sure your solution can handle such scenarios gracefully.
As you iterate through the fruits array, check how far you can go in both left and right directions. This will help you determine the optimal path to take for maximum harvest.
When calculating the total fruits harvested, you might want to maintain a running total as you explore each position. This will help you easily compare different paths.
Consider how you can efficiently determine which positions are reachable within your k steps. You might need to calculate distances dynamically as you explore.
If you decide to use a loop to explore positions, ensure that you are not exceeding your step limit k at any point. This will be crucial for maintaining the validity of your movements.
Think about how to handle the case when you reach the end of the fruits array. You need to ensure you don't try to access positions that are out of bounds.
Finally, try to sketch out a plan for your algorithm. You might want to outline how you will use loops or recursion to explore the positions and calculate the maximum fruits harvested.

questionNotes: The fruits array is sorted by position and contains unique positions.
You can move left or right, but you cannot exceed k steps in total.
Fruits at your starting position can be harvested immediately.
Fruits disappear after being harvested, so keep track of what you've collected.
Consider edge cases where k is 0 or very small, and where no fruits are reachable.
